utterances: In his mid-20s, he asked his friends to call him Christopher and to refer to him as he instead if she.
Lee lived the rest of his adult life as a man.
In 2012, when he was 48, he committed suicide.
His friends were left grieving, not just his death, but what happened after.
They explained to the coroner that Lee was transgender.
They turned over his driver's license with his sex indicated with a capital M.
But when the death certificate came back, Christopher was listed as Kristina.
Sex - female.
It felt like spitting on his grave.
That Christopher's close friend, Maya Scott-Chung.
I just felt like Christopher's spirit will not rest in peace with a death certificate that says female.
Scott-Chung made her way to the office of California legislator Toni Atkins.
Atkins drafted a law saying death certificates for transgender people should be filled out according to the person's gender identity rather than anatomy.
At a hearing in Sacramento, she explained that only a fraction of transgender people ever have sex reassignment surgery.
It's not uncommon for a transgender person to retain some physical characteristics of the gender assigned to them at birth even though they have transitioned to a new gender identity.
That can leave coroners in a quandary.
Christopher Lee was taking testosterone when he died.
The medical examiner described the body at the autopsy - a short mustache and beard, a receding hairline consistent with male balding, and female genitalia.
That's why the F ended up on the death certificate.
We don't have a lot of leeway in that.
That's Lieutenant Riddic Bowers of the Alameda County Coroner's Bureau.
He says a driver's license is not enough to override anatomy.
We have to rely on someone's existing birth certificate and their correlating anatomical description.
If there's any confusion, next of kin is consulted.
And this is the heart of the controversy.
Many transgender people are estranged from relatives who are uncomfortable with their gender transition.
Lt.
Bowers says his staff isn't allowed to take the word of close friends or chosen family.
If they're not blood related, they're not family.
Legally, they just have no say.
The new law in California changes two key things.
First, it requires coroners and funeral directors to record a person's gender identity rather than anatomical sex on the death certificate.
Second, if there's a dispute, a driver's license or passport will trump family opinion.
Christopher Lee's father and sister declined to be interviewed for this story.
In the end, they asked Lee's friends to settle his affairs.
For Maya Scott-Chung, that meant doing more than clearing out his closets.
That meant continuing the spirit of Lee's activism and changing the law.
We really - we hope that everyone can honor and respect their loved ones in their death.
She plans to get Lee's death certificate changed as soon as the law takes effect in July.
For NPR News, I'm April Dembosky in San Francisco.
In China, it is not unusual to come across names like this.
Cinderella
Billboard.
Mo Money.
Lady Gaga.
These are all English names adopted by young Chinese in hopes of interacting more easily with Westerners.
But such names sometimes have the opposite effect, so an American entrepreneur set up a new website to help young people in China choose more appropriate names.
NPR's Frank Langfitt reports from Shanghai.
When Lindsay Jernigan was working at her first job in Shanghai, she noticed some of her female colleagues had English names that were just way off.
These names that as we would see them in a connotation as stripper names for really smart, young women.
And so I've heard a lot of people laughing about, you know, there's the Candy and the Cherry and Sapphire, Twinkle.
Other names just created confusion.
For example, someone's name was Eleven.
Scheduling meeting times at 10:30 and then saying that Eleven was coming was causing a lot of issues.
People always rolling their eyes like, Eleven, and asking, what's your Chinese name?
Can we just call you by your Chinese name?
And therefore, have strong connections to that community and - or least that point of view.
Mm-hmm.
The story of a missing British girl has captured headlines in Europe this summer.
She disappeared while her family was vacationing on the southern coast of Portugal in a region called the Algarve.
Interest in the fate of 4-year-old Madeleine McCann has been compared with interest in Princess Diana.
Some are asking why the case is getting so much attention.
Jerome Socolovsky reports from Praia da Luz.
This could be any beach in Southern Europe.
I think a volleyball game is underway.
Children dig in the sand.
And small white fishing boats ride at anchor just off the shore.
It's as though nothing sinister happened here in this picture postcard Algarve village.
But Praia da Luz, which means the shore of light, has become synonymous around Europe with the bright-eyed little girl that went missing here.
On May 3rd, Madeleine McCann was sleeping in her room with her 2-year-old twin siblings.
Their parents were out dining at a nearby restaurant.
When they returned, she was gone.
What happened next has surprised almost everyone.
Posters of Madeleine have been plastered around Europe.
E-mail chains plead for information on her whereabouts, and hundreds of videos have been posted on YouTube.
(Soundbite of YouTube clip)
If you have seen this little girl, please, could you go to your local authorities or police and give any information that you have, any genuine information that you have.
Soccer star David Beckham posted this appeal.
He has been joined by ""Harry Potter"" author J.K.
Rowling and other celebrities in the campaign that has raised around $2 million for the effort to find Madeleine.
Her parents, Kate and Gerry McCann have stayed on in Praia da Luz and devoted themselves to keeping their daughter's case in the spotlight.
They've given countless interviews and started to find Madeleine Web site.
Many Europeans are baffled as to why this case has gotten so much attention.
One reason may be that it's so easy to have an opinion.
Frankly, there's no excuse for leaving your children at home unattended when the Portuguese people in the restaurants are so friendly.
Jim Parish has been bringing his family to Praia da Luz for years.
His 5-year-old daughter, with freckles and flowing red hair, clings to his side.
I could understand if they're back in England because it's not looked upon in the same way when you come out with children at night.
Over here, the Portuguese are so friendly.
And they will bring our children out to attend them from (unintelligible) anyway.
Many Portuguese are a little resentful of all the attention.
Lui Gonsalvez(ph) is especially critical of Portuguese authorities.
(Portuguese spoken)
We in Portugal have had a lot of similar cases.
But our police haven't made any effort to find them, he says.
This case, Madeleine's case, involved so many people - the British police and the Portuguese police - and I'm sorry to say, they haven't done the same for the Portuguese children.
Here in Praia da Luz, some people, Portuguese and British, just want life to go back to the way it was.
At Kelly's Bar in town, an angry proprietor refuses to let a reporter ask his customers about their views on the disappearance.
Unidentified Man #1: If you're not leaving, (unintelligible).
So get people respected.
Unidentified Man #2: No, I'm just asking them questions.
Tourism is down in Praia da Luz.
But the media vans with their satellite dishes are still lined up at the Ocean Club resort where the crime occurred.
Inez Pereida(ph) is the Algarve correspondent for Portuguese TVI television.
She has been here since day one.
People don't feel very - a little bit upset because we are so many journalists here.
Portuguese, Finnish, British, Germany, everybody, French, everybody is here.
Radio, television, newspapers - so, so many people.
They get tired but at the same time they understand that we have to do our job.
